passages.name: 01 Comfort
passages.label: Comfort
passages.text:
[Image: She's got something running down her leg... wonder who did that!
"Just weeding the stone garden, love." I tear into a honey cake, still hot enough to burn my fingers. Worth it. "Just plucking weeds before they choke the crop."

She sets down a mug of bark tea with more force than necessary. "That's what you said about the cockatrice."

"The cockatrice barely nicked me."

"You came home with half your chest hanging open!"

I catch her wrist, gentle. "That was two years ago. And I learned my lesson about checking corners."

"Did you?" She's not really angry. Just worried. I can read it in how she keeps touching things - the table, her locket, the bread knife. "Because Giles offered to go with you. Said so yesterday at market."

"Giles." I snort. "Good man with a sword, but Goblins don't give a thrack about swords. They care about fire. Wind. The kind of forces that make them remember why they used to fear humans."

"They *used* to fear us?"

"Before they learned we're soft." I pull her onto my lap. She resists for half a heartbeat, then melts against me. "That's why they're getting bold. Coming out of the eastern wastes, sniffing around our borders. Testing."

"Testing for what?"

I don't answer that. Don't tell her about the patterns I've been noticing. She's got enough to worry about.

"You're doing that thing," she says against my shoulder.

"What thing?"

"That thing where you go quiet because you think I can't handle the truth."

Six years and she reads me like one of her garden almanacs.

"The *truth* is," I say carefully, "twelve goblins in a mine is nothing. The truth is I've cleared three times that many from tighter spaces. The truth isâ€”"

[Video]

"The truth is you're going alone." She pulls back, pins me with that drowning-deep stare. "Again."

"Someone has to stay and protect the town."

"From what? Mean old Mrs. Curdsworth and her attack chickens?"

That makes me laugh. "Those chickens *are* vicious."

She doesn't smile. "Train more knights, Aldric. Like you used to. Before you decided you had to do everything yourself."

"I don't do everythingâ€”"

"Name the last threat you let the guard handle."

I open my mouth. Close it. She's got me there.

"See?" She stands, starts clearing plates with sharp, efficient movements. "The great Aldric. Has to bear every burden. Fight every fight. Because gods forbid someone else mightâ€”"

"Might die." The words come out harder than intended. "Might die because I wasn't there. Because I let them go instead."

The plate in her hand stills. "Oh, love."

"Goblins go for the eyes first," I tell her. "Then the throat. Then they drag you down and let the little ones practice their knife work while you're still breathing. I've seen it. I've seen what happens when good men underestimate them."

She sets down the plate, comes back to me. Her hands frame my face. "And you've seen what happens when you try to carry the world alone. You come home bleeding. Every time, a little more of you doesn't come back."

Her being right doesn't change what needs doing.

"After the mine," I promise. "After I clear it, I'll talk to Giles about training. Maybe take on a few of the younger guards. Teach them what to watch for."

"Really?"

"Really." I kiss her palm. "But today, I make sure those green bastards remember why they stay in the wastes."

She sighs but nods. "At least eat more first. You burned a lot of energy this morning."

"Whose fault is that?"

"Yours." She turns back to the stove, and yes, she's absolutely making sure I see how my tunic rides up. "You're the one who married me."

"Best mistake I ever made."

"Mistake?" She spins, brandishing a wooden spoon like Whisperwind.

"Best decision. Best blessing. Bestâ€”"

"Better." She points the spoon at my plate. "Now eat. Heroes don't fight on empty stomachs.""Actually could be tricky." I drag my thumb along the table's grain, thinking. "Scout reports say they've fortified. Barricades. Maybe even crude traps."

Elara pauses mid-pour, honey dripping from the pot. "Fortified? Since when do Goblins fortify?"

"Since about three months ago." I keep my voice level. No need to worry her with speculation. "Started seeing it out near the border settlements."

"That's... not normal goblin behavior."

"No." I tear off a chunk of bread, use it to soak up the bacon grease. "It's not."

She abandons the honey entirely, sits across from me. "Aldric. What aren't you telling me?"

"Nothing confirmed." But I can see she won't let this go. "Someone's teaching them. Or something. The patterns are too deliberate. Too..." I search for the word. "Human."

"Human?" Her voice pitches higher. "You think someone's helping them?"

"I think someone's using them." Big difference. "Goblins are tools. Always have been. The question is who's wielding them now."

She reaches across the table, grips my hand. "Then you definitely shouldn't go alone. If they're organizedâ€”"

"If they're organized, they're still goblins." I turn her hand over, trace the calluses from her garden work. Strong hands. "Fire still makes them scatter. Wind still throws off their aim. And Whisperwind still cuts through them like parchment."

"But if there's someone behind themâ€”"

"Then I'll find out who." I squeeze her fingers. "That's my purpose. I track. I hunt. I end things."

"You make it sound so simple."

"It is simple. Just not easy."

She pulls her hand back, stands abruptly. "Giles could help. He offered yesterday."

"Giles is a good soldier. But soldiers make noise. Soldiers follow patterns." I watch her pace, nervous energy crackling off her. "I need to be smoke today. Silent. Unpredictable."

[Video]

"You need to be careful."

"I'm alwaysâ€”"

"Don't." She whirls on me. "Don't say you're always careful. Not when you came home last month with troll poison in your veins. Not when youâ€”"

"That was different."

"How?"

"That was a troll. This is goblins."

"Organized goblins! Fortified goblins! Goblins with a puppet master!"

She's spiraling. I stand, catch her shoulders. "Elara. Look at me."

Those sapphire eyes are bright with unshed tears. Shit.

"I've been fighting goblins since I was fourteen," I tell her. "My first kill was a goblin. My first scarâ€”" I guide her hand to the pale line on my ribs, "â€”was a goblin. I know them. Know how they think, how they move, how they smell when they're afraid."

"Butâ€”"

"And they know me." I let that sink in. "The ones who survive? They tell stories. About the human who brings wind and fire. Who moves through shadows. Who leaves no survivors when they threaten what's his."

Her breath shudders out. "You're trying to scare me."

"Then be reassured." I pull her close, feel her heart racing against mine. "Twelve goblins in a mine, organized or not, are still just twelve goblins. I've faced worse with less. And I alwaysâ€”alwaysâ€”come home to you."

She makes a sound that's half laugh, half sob. "You better. We're trying for a baby, remember? Can't do that if you're dead."

"Wouldn't dream of it." I kiss the top of her head. "Besides, who'd eat all your honey cakes?"

"Over my dead body."

"That's what I'm trying to avoid!" But she's smiling now, crisis passed. "Fine. Go. Be the hero. But if you're not back by sunsetâ€”"

"You'll come looking. I know." I give her ass a quick pat as I head for the stairs. "Keep that tunic on. I want to peel it off you when I get back."

She's not wrong."Remember that green bastard from our wedding?" I wave my honey cake for emphasis. "His cousins showed up."

Elara's eyes narrow. "Aldric."

"He was very rude. Didn't even bring a gift."

"There were no Goblins at our wedding." She's trying not to smile. Failing.

"They do love parties though. All that screaming and chaosâ€”"

The wooden spoon hits my shoulder.

I catch her wrist, pull her onto my lap. "I'm seriously going to kill some goblins."

"You're seriously impossible." But she's melting against me, can't help it. We fit together like Whisperwind in her sheath.

"Here's serious." I kiss her neck, that spot that makes her shiver. "They're dug into the Ironrock. Got there three nights ago. Probably found the old overseer's office, think they're clever."

"And?" Her fingers find my hair.

"And they're about to learn what happens when goblins get too close to what's mine." Another kiss, just below her ear. "The mine. The town." Kiss. "You."

"You can't justâ€”mmmâ€”distract me withâ€”"

"Watch me." I stand, lifting her with me. She squeaks, wraps her legs around my waist. "I've been killing goblins since before Eon's beard went gray."

"Your confidence is going to get you killed."

"My confidence got me you."

She pulls back, studies my face. Those eyesâ€”winter-lake blue, fathoms deepâ€”see everything. The jokes. The bravado. The cold certainty underneath. "Burn them all."

"Every last one."

"Good." She kisses me, fierce and quick. "Now put me down. Heroes don't fight on empty stomachs, and you've barely touched your bacon."

"I've been touching something better."

"Eat your breakfast, you *beast!*"

Whisperwind waits on her stand like a patient lover. The morning light through our bedroom window makes her shimmerâ€”the color of lightning frozen mid-strike. I lift her, feel her weight settle into my palm like a handshake. Always true.

The enchantments hum against my skin. Something dreams inside the bladeâ€”Whisperwind's alive in her way. Waiting. Eager.

"Miss me?" I murmur, checking her edge. Still sharp enough to split sunlight. The wind runes along her fuller pulse faintly, responding to my touch.

My armor takes longer. Elara helps with the buckles I can't reach, her fingers steady and practiced. Six years of this routine. Six years of sending me off to danger.

"Too tight?" she asks, adjusting the pauldron.

"Perfect."

She always asks. I always say perfect. It's our ritual, important as any prayer to the Ephemerals.

The breastplate goes on last. Mythril-touched steel, worth more than our house. Worth it, though. The amount of times it's turned a blade that should've killed me...

I kiss her, deep and thorough. "I'll come home."

"So do goblins." He eyes Whisperwind. "Need anything? Got new whetstones from the capital. Some decent torch oil."

"Course you are." He turns back to his cart, then pauses. "My daughter wants to know if you'll teach her swordwork."

His relief's visible. "Appreciated."

The kids find me at the fountain. Seven of them today, wooden swords and pot-lid shields, playing at heroes.

"Aldric! Aldric!" Little Sara, gap-toothed and fierce. "You gonna fight monsters?"

I let them squabble, but I'm watching the shadows. Watching how the morning light falls. Calculating angles, distances. These kids don't know how close the darkness really is. Don't know what waits past their walls.

Good. Let them play at heroes a little longer.

"Aldric's gonna win," Sara declares. "He always wins. That's why he's The Great!"

If only.

passages.text:
[Image: Eboncrest rises where the Pitchwater meets pine.
Mayor Bramble finds me at the west gate, already sweating through his doublet. But the man keeps Eboncrest running smooth as dwarf-forged steel, and that counts for something.

"Aldric." He's breathing hard from the walk. Probably came straight from his morning ledgers. "Thank the Ephemerals you're here."

"Mayor." I adjust Whisperwind's weight at my side. The guards at the gate give us space, but they're listening.

"The situation at Ironrockâ€”" He mops his forehead with a silk kerchief that costs more than most miners see in a month. "We've had to halt all operations. That's three days of ore we're not pulling. The smelters are sitting idle. The whole supply chain to the capital..."

The driver, old Henrik's boy, tips his cap to me. I nod back. Kid lost two fingers to a wyvern last harvestâ€”still drives better than his father.

"How many men did you lose?" I ask.

"None dead, Flux be praised. But seven injured in the retreat. They say the goblins have built *something* down there. Barricades. Maybe worse." His jowls quiver with each word. "The miners, they're talking about... structures. Old stonework they broke through last week."

My spine straightens. "Stonework?"

"Old things. Carvings. The kind the scholars in Thuulk pay gold for." He drops his voice.

A kid kicks a leather ball past us, chasing chickens.

"The goblins found it first?"

"Seems so. Moved right in once our boys broke through." Bramble pulls a scroll from his vest. "The mine foreman drew this. What they could see before they ran."

I study the rough sketch. Pillars. Arched doorways too tall for dwarves, too ornate for early human work. My jaw tightens.

"I'll clear them out," I tell him. "Send the miners back tomorrow morning with a double guard shift."

"Tomorrow? Aldric, there could be dozensâ€”"

"There aren't." I hand back the scroll. "Dozen, maybe fifteen at most. Goblins can't think past their next meal. They find a hole, they squat in it until someone makes them leave."

[Image: Bramble's built like a baker's mistakeâ€”too much dough, not enough time in the oven.

Mrs. Fletcher waddles up, her arms full of fresh bread. "Morning, Mayor. Aldric." She pushes a warm loaf into my hands. "For the road. Can't have our hero fighting on an empty stomach."

"Already ate, Mrs. Fletcher. My wifeâ€”"

"That lovely Elara made you breakfast, did she?" Her eyes twinkle. "Good. Girl knows how to keep a man's strength up. When are you two giving us some little warriors to run around town?"

The mayor coughs. "Mrs. Fletcher, perhapsâ€”"

"We're working on it," I say, which makes her cackle and waddle off.

Bramble watches her go, then turns back to me. "The iron shipments to the capital are already two days behind. The guild representatives are breathing down my neck. If this isn't resolvedâ€”"

"It will be."

"You're certain you don't need support? Captain Giles has volunteersâ€”"

"Giles is a good man and a good fighter." I check my pouchesâ€”sulfur, salt, the usual implements. "Goblins in a mine need fire and wind to keep things clean. It will be close quarters. Can't have a bunch of guards getting in each other's way."

He nods, but his face says he's calculating lost revenue by the hour. "The structures they foundâ€”you'll send word about what's down there?"

"After I burn out the goblins."

"Of course. Of course." He's already backing away, eager to return to his numbers and ledgers. "The town's counting on you, Aldric. As always."

"As always."

He hurries off, probably to threaten the mining guild with penalties if they don't resume operations tomorrow. I head for the gate. The guards straighten as I pass.

"Send them to the Hollow, Aldric," one mutters.

[Choice: Journey to Ironrock Mine.

passages.name: 01 leave for ironrock
passages.label: Leave For Ironrock
passages.text:
The King's Road carries me west through morning mist. Pine needles crunch under my boots, that sharp green smell mixing with damp earth. The forest here grows thickâ€”old growth that remembers when goblins were just bad dreams told to children.

Three miners trudge toward me, pulling a handcart loaded with personal effects. Walking with the slow certainty of men who'd seen enough.

"Morning, Aldric." The lead miner, Henrik's cousin by his jaw, doesn't quite meet my eyes. "Figured we'd see you coming."

"How many?" I ask.

"Can't say for certain." He spits tobacco juice into the ferns. "Enough. They came up through the new shaft we broke last sennight. The one with the old stonework."

"Anyone hurt?"

"Not our team. Bruises. Pride, mostly. We locked the upper galleries and got out clean." He shifts the cart handles. "They're... settling in. Like they plan to stay."

I nod. "Mine'll be clear by sunset. Tell Bramble to send the next shift at dawn."

They continue west. I continue east. The forest knows what's comingâ€”birds gone quiet, even the insects holding their breath.

Fresh wheel ruts cut deep in mud. Someone left in a hurryâ€”probably with a full load, too.

Then I smell it.

Goblin stench hits like a wall. Unwashed bodies layered over something worseâ€”the musk of things that rut in darkness and eat their own dead. My gorge rises. I breathe through my mouth, but that's worse. Now I can taste it.

The path opens into the mine's staging area. Abandoned equipment everywhereâ€”pickaxes dropped mid-swing, lunch pails still steaming, a card game interrupted, copper coins scattered across a crate. They didn't run. They just... left. Orderly. Like they knew exactly what not to fight.

Dark stains on the ground near the entrance. Goblin marking fluidâ€”acrid, territorial. They're claiming territory. My jaw clenches thinking of what that means. In the frontier villages, girls disappear. Not killedâ€”worse. Kept. Bred. Some get rescued sennights later, hollow-eyed and babbling. Some get found years later with broods of green-skinned spawn, too far gone to even remember their own names.

Not here. Not in my territory.

The entrance yawns before me. Fresh goblin tracks in the mudâ€”clawed feet, some dragging weapons, one set dragging something heavier.

My hand closes on Whisperwind's grip. The blade hums, eager. Good. Because behind that stench, beneath the musk and territorial pissingâ€”stone dust. Old stone dust. Whatever the miners broke through last week, the goblins found it first.

They'll have numbers, knowledge of the tunnels, maybe crude traps. They'll fight dirtyâ€”groin strikes, eye gouging, tried to hamstring. They always do.

I crack my neck. Flex my fingers. The killing-calm settles over me like old armor. Heartbeat slows. Breathing deepens.

Time to remind them why goblins used to hide from men.

passages.name: 01 mine
passages.label: Mine
passages.text:
The darkness swallows me whole.

Mine air lands heavy in the chestâ€”thick, wet, with weight behind it. My eyes adjust slow. The entrance tunnel slopes down, support beams every ten feet. Some are cracked. Some are missing. The floor's uneven where cart tracks cut grooves decades deep.

Whisperwind slides from her sheath. The faint scrape of steel on leather sounds loud as thunder down here. I keep the blade low, ready for the upward cut that opens goblin throats.

Right hand on the wall. Always keep contact in the dark. The stone sweatsâ€”groundwater seeping through limestone. My fingers trace tool marks, then something else. Scratches. Fresh. Goblin claws marking territory like dogs pissing on posts.

I test each plank before trusting my weight. Second rule of mine fighting: the ground lies. Goblins love pit traps, love watching men fall onto stakes smeared with their shit. The wood groans but holds.

Deeper now. The stench thickensâ€”unwashed bodies, rotting meat, and underneath it all, that sweet-sick musk. My stomach clenches.

Thereâ€”a broken helmet in the muck. Not dropped. Crushed. Tooth marks punch through the iron like it's parchment. Whatever bit through this wasn't satisfied with just killing.

The tunnel branches ahead. I can hear them nowâ€”that chittering speech that sounds like someone choking on their own tongue. At least three voices. Maybe five. They're not trying to hide. Why would they? This is their domain now.

I drop to one knee, scoop a handful of pebbles. Whisper the word that wakes wind.

"Ventusfury."

Just a breath of magic, enough to carry the pebbles' rattle down the left passage. The chittering stops.

Good.

The main passage opens into a wider chamber ahead. I can make out their shapesâ€”three goblins arranged in a loose picket line. The other two have rusty mining picks, probably pulled from dead men's hands. They're focused on the side passage where my pebbles landed.

The dance begins.

]Magic. Scholars view it as a conversation; I view it as a truncheon. Application trumps raw power. A wizard might level this whole hillside, certainlyâ€”and bury us all in a thousand tons of rock. I use magic the way a butcher uses a boning knife: seeking the joint, severing the connection, wasting nothing.

The hedge wizard who taught meâ€”Gannis, dying of gut-rot in a ditch outside Westmarchâ€”he grabbed my wrist when I gave him water. "Not... charity," he'd gasped through blood-foam. "Payment."

Three days I sat with him while he died. Three days he poured the Telenil battle-tongue into my skull. The war words. The cuts and thrusts of combat casting.

"Shape... matters more than... than power," Gannis had wheezed, his fingers forcing mine into the proper forms. "The Telenil know... thousand years of... of killing with grace."

Ventusfury. Wind as weapon, scout, and voice.

Glacieshold. Ice-grip. But deeper: the moment water chooses sides, becomes wall or trap or death.

Ignisurge. The difference between light and cremation.

Any fool can say the words. The hand-shapes, the breath-timing, the intent behind the gestureâ€”that's what makes fire obey.

[Image: Ventusfury in its smallest form, a mouse's breath of wind.

I pause at the first support beam. Thumb and forefinger snapâ€”barely a sound. It tells me everything: air flows toward me along the floor (they've got fire deeper in), away from me at head height (gas pocket forming). Sweet-rot smell like overripe pearsâ€”firedamp. One spark up there and we all cook.

My left hand forms the ice-ready position: three fingers curved like holding a river stone. The mine's moisture beads on my palm, ready to become whatever I need. Two frozen coins already pressed to my beltâ€”door seals if needed. The cold helps me think.

Ahead, water drips. But the rhythm's wrong. Too regular.

Drip. Drip. Drip-drip.

Another micro-pulse of wind, directed left into a side passage. It comes back tasting of leather and goblin piss. They're there, waiting.

I roll my shoulders, feel Whisperwind's weight shift. The blade's quietâ€”it knows this is spell-work first. My right hand practices the Ignisurge forms: thumb-spark for precision, two-finger lance for cutting. Gannis made me drill these until my fingers bled, to distract himself from his own pain.

"The Telenil," he'd said on his last day, "they see magic as... as conversation. You're not commandingâ€”you're... convincing. Fire wants to burn. Ice wants to still. Wind wants to move. You just... suggest directions."

The tunnel splits ahead. Both passages dark, but the darkness has different qualities. Left is thickâ€”bodies and barriers. Right is thinâ€”open space but angled wrong.

I palm one ice coin. The moisture in the air crystallizes along my knuckles, eager. Ready.

Something shifts in the left passage. Metal on leather.

My boot lands on a dry patch in the tunnel floor. Too dry. Everything else is seeping moisture, but this one square yard is bone-dry.

I sidestep, pressing against the wet wall. Another wind-pulse, this one carrying a pebble's sound to that dry spot.

*Thwick.* A sling stone cracks where I should have been standing. Behind a slotted screen twenty feet ahead, someone curses in goblinâ€”sounds like "Grashk."

Blood-debt comes due.

The rime spreads from my palm across the tunnel floorâ€”invisible in the dark, thin as paper, cold enough to seize. If they rush, they'll hit it like a wall. My left hand maintains that while my right forms the spark position.

Gannis's last words bubble up from memory: "Magic isn't... isn't strength. It's knowing. Know what burns. What freezes. What moves. Then... then you just... help it along."

No risk at hand-height. The gas floats. I let it fly.

The slat screen explodes in light. A goblin squealsâ€”night vision murdered. I taste copper and smoke, but controlled. Surgical. Something deeper in the mine drums once.

They know I'm here. They know I'm hunting.

Good.

passages.name: 01 combat
passages.label: Combat
passages.text:
The cross-brace hangs lowâ€”meant for mining carts, not men. I slide beneath it, spine scraping wood, Whisperwind reversed in my grip.

The first goblin never sees me coming.

My pommel strikes the soft spot where skull meets spine. The crack is wet, muffled. He drops like a sack of grain. I catch him before he hits ground, lower him silent into the muck. His sling stones scatterâ€”I palm three.

The second goblin starts to turn. I'm already moving.

Whisperwind knows this dance. The blade shifts in my handâ€”a living thing that remembers every fight we've shared. I bring her up in a reversed grip, the false edge finding the sweet spot under his jaw. The cut is clean, surgical. He tries to scream but I've already opened his windpipe. Just a wheeze and he's down, drowning in his own blood.

The third one sees his partner fall.

"Ventusfury," I breathe.

The slinger's raising his weapon. My wind pushes his elbow just as he releasesâ€”the stone meant for my skull cracks into the ceiling instead. He's fumbling for another stone when Whisperwind's point catches his heart.

Three heartbeats. Three corpses.

I wipe the blade clean on the slinger's rags. That's when I see themâ€”human eyes threaded on gut-string like a necklace. Still wet. Still warm. The irises are blue.

Deeper in, I hear shuffling. Careful movement. They know something's wrong but not what.

Let the wondering gnaw them hollow.

The tunnel narrows ahead, then opens into what must have been the overseer's station. I can see lamplight bleeding around a doorframe. They're falling back, trying to fortify.

[Choice: Advance on the barricaded office.]The ore wedge sits loose against the wallâ€”a triangular chunk of iron meant to split rock. My boot sends it clattering loud as thunder.

All three goblins turn toward the sound.

I'm already moving the opposite direction. Three long strides right, making sure my boots ring against stone. The slinger tracks the sound, arm drawing back. The two with picks start forward.

Then I cut left, hard.

Whisperwind singsâ€”that sweet metallic note that means death is coming. The blade catches what little light exists down here, becomes a silver arc in the darkness.

"Ignisurge!"

Fire blooms from my left handâ€”a blinding flash, nothing more. Brilliant orange light explodes across their night-adapted eyes. They shriek, hands flying to their faces.

Whisperwind takes the first goblin at the kneesâ€”parts flesh like water, skyforged edge through bone like bread. He topples. My return stroke opens his throat before he hits the ground.

The second swings wild. I step inside the arc, shoulder into his chest, pommel into his nose. Spin the blade. His guts hit the floor before he understands he's dead.

The slinger blinks, loads a stone. I throw the gutted corpse at him. It hits him square and I'm already lunging, Whisperwind threading his ribs, leaning on the blade until I feel it scrape against his heart. His eyes go wide, then empty.

I pull the blade free. Around the slinger's neckâ€”a necklace of human eyes on gut-string. Still glistening. Irises blue as summer sky.

The sound of my attack echoes deep into the mine. Chittering voices rise in alarm. Feet slapping on wet stoneâ€”lots of feet, moving fast. They're retreating deeper, toward the lower galleries.

[Choice: Pursue them into the depths.]The pebble arcs through the darkness. As it flies, I whisper: "Ventusfury."

Wind carries the stone further than any throw should, bouncing it off the far wall with a crack that echoes like a whip. Two goblins immediately peel off, picks raised, chittering excitedly as they investigate.

Perfect.

"Glacieshold."

Ice spreads from my palm, racing across the floor in a thin sheet. It pools around the ankles of the remaining goblin and the slinger, freezing their feet to the stone. They shriek, trying to pull free.

The two investigating goblins hear their panic, start to turn back.

Too late.

Whisperwind slides free with the sound of a lover's sigh. The blade knows my intent before I doâ€”already shifting its weight for the work ahead. I move like fever through blood, like grief through a widow's house.

The first goblin rounds the corner into my thrust. Whisperwind takes him through the eye, the tip punching out the back of his skull with a wet crack. I don't even slowâ€”just let his momentum carry him off the blade as I pivot toward his partner.

This one manages to raise his pick. I let him.

The pick comes down. Whisperwind rises to meet it. The weapons clashâ€”crude iron against skyforged steelâ€”and the pick shatters like glass. Metal fragments pepper his face. While he's screaming, I open him from groin to throat with a rising cut that parts flesh like silk.

Back to the frozen ones.

The slinger's managed to load a stone despite his trapped feet. He releases. I don't dodgeâ€”I *flow* around it, Whisperwind's flat redirecting the projectile into the wall. The blade continues its arc, taking his hand at the wrist. The hand hits the ground still clutching the sling.

The last goblin's torn his feet free, leaving skin behind on the ice. He hobbles toward a side passage, mewling.

Whisperwind's point finds his spine. He drops, paralyzed but breathing. I step over him, following his terrified gaze.

Thereâ€”strung between two posts like a grotesque bannerâ€”a necklace of human eyes threaded on gut-string. Still wet. Still warm. The irises are blue.

Behind me, the paralyzed goblin whimpers. I finish him quickâ€”he doesn't deserve quick, but I need to move. More voices echo from below. They're retreating, but organized. Controlled.

[Choice: Pursue them into the depths.]The corridor ahead bends left. A cluster of goblins waitâ€”I can smell them.

Time to teach them about ice.

Glacieshold.

The word flows through my fingers as I shape the spell. Ice spreads from my palm across the tunnel floorâ€”not flat, but sloped. A clean V-shape, walls to center, funneling toward the doorway ahead. I leave a raised ridge down the middle. Their feet will slide sideways into the trap.

I tap Whisperwind's pommel against the left wall. The sound echoes.

"Grashk! There!" A goblin voice, excited. Young. Stupid.

The slinger steps into viewâ€”green skin glistening with sweat, yellow eyes wide, erection tenting his loincloth because violence always gets them hard. He draws back his sling.

Ignisurge.

My fingers snap forward. A line of pure heat cuts the air, visible for just a heartbeatâ€”bright as lightning, thin as wire. The sling cord parts mid-swing. The stone drops. The goblin stares at his useless weapon.

"KILL HIM!" Two more goblins charge around the corner, feet hitting my ice.

Beautiful.

They slide immediately, arms windmilling. The V-shape does its workâ€”both skid inward toward the center ridge. One trips. The other stumbles over him. They're tangled, cursing, trying to stand on ice that won't let them.

Glacieshold.

This time I'm specific. Ice forms around their anklesâ€”thick, instant, permanent. They're welded to my trap.

"Magic!" one screams. "He's usingâ€”"

Ignisurge.

A thumb-flick sends a spark into the slinger's eyes. He shrieks, pawing at his face. Behind him, two more goblins appear. One's carrying an oil pot.

The fear hits them now. That beautiful moment when they realize they're not fighting some lucky humanâ€”they're fighting someone who turns combat into art.

The oil-carrier panics, hurls his pot.

Glacieshold.

Ice springs from my forearmâ€”a shield, paper-thin but harder than steel. The oil splashes against it.

Ventusfury.

Wind shoves the oil back along the ice floor, under their feet.

Ignisurge.

A tiny spark. The oil ignites behind them, cutting off retreat. They're mine now.

I stride forward down the center ridge, balanced while they slip and scramble. The ankle-frozen goblins try to swing at me. I'm already past them. My boot crushes the first one's knee sideways. The crack echoes. My elbow catches the second's jawâ€”teeth scatter across ice like dice.

The slinger's still blind, sobbing. A head-butt drops him.

The remaining two goblins jam in the doorway, trying to flee the flames behind them.

Perfect.

]The tunnel opens up. Sixâ€”no, eight goblins. Green skin glistening with mine-damp, wearing scraps of leather and stolen mail. The nearest one grins, showing teeth filed to points.

They think numbers matter.

Ignisurge.

Fire blooms from my palm, a wave of orange death that rolls forward at waist height. The front two goblins shriek as their leather burns through, flesh blistering instantly. They drop their rusted blades, stumbling back into their brothers.

I step through the gap I've made.

A goblin lunges from my left. My shoulder, plated in steel, catches him in the teeth. Bone cracks. As he staggers, I pivot, bringing my right hand around in an arc. Fire follows the motion, a burning whip that catches three of them across their bellies. The smell of charred meat fills the tunnel.

They're screaming now.

At the back, one goblin clutches a clay jarâ€”oil, by the way he holds it like a baby. His yellow eyes are wide, measuring the killing-space between us. Another has a sling, stone already whirring.

The stone clips my cheek. Too close.

I drop to one knee, left palm snapping forward. A fist-sized fireball punches through a wooden shield, exploding behind it. The goblin holding it falls backward, chest smoking. The others freeze for a heartbeatâ€”that beautiful moment when bravado becomes terror.

The oil-carrier's hands shake. His cock has shriveled back into his loincloth. Fear does that.

passages.name: 01 barricade
passages.label: Barricade
passages.text:
[[Image: The door's solid oak reinforcedâ€”meant to protect payroll from desperate miners.
I can hear them inside. Furniture scraping. Bottles clinking. They're building a barricade, but they're also preparing something else. The smell of lamp oil cuts through the usual goblin stench.

The office overlooks the main shaft through a narrow window. Smart defensive positionâ€”if I hadn't fought in a hundred rat's nests just like it.

They've stacked desks against the door. Through the gap beneath, I see shadows moving. Four, maybe five. Two near the back are doing something with clay jugs. Oil bombs.

Typical goblin tacticsâ€”when you can't win clean, burn everything.

The door won't budge. They've braced it well.[Video]

"Ventusfury!"

I don't whisper it this time. I roar it.

Wind explodes from my palmsâ€”a hammering gale that hits the door like a giant's fist. The wood splinters. Iron bands buckle. The entire frame tears free from the stone, crashing outward and bringing the desk-barricade with it.

I'm through before the dust settles.

The room's smaller than expectedâ€”fifteen feet square, ceiling sagging with timber rot. An oil lamp swings from a chain, casting wild shadows. Two goblins with jugs of oil stand frozen by the back wall. Three others scramble over the destroyed furniture, reaching for weapons.

Whisperwind takes the first one across the eyes. The blade moves like thoughtâ€”no hesitation between decision and action. Blood sprays across yellowed invoices still tacked to the wall.

I let him swing. At the last second, I step inside his reach, catch his wrist with my free hand. My knee drives into his elbowâ€”the joint bends backward with a crack like breaking kindling. While he screams, Whisperwind opens his throat.

The oil-throwers are recovering. One's got a burning rag ready.

"Glacieshold!"

Ice erupts across the floor, racing up their legs, freezing the oil in their jugs solid. The one with the burning rag drops it in panic. The flame hits the ice, sputters out.

The remaining two goblins charge together, mining picks raised. Smartâ€”coordinated attacks are harder to counter.

Whisperwind flows through the Seventh Formâ€”an extension of arm, rage, and thirty years of killing. Deflect, redirect, riposte. Their picks spark against skyforged steel. One goblin's momentum carries him past me. Whisperwind's edge bites through his hamstring. He falls, screaming.

The last one backs against the wall, pick trembling in his grip.

I advance slow. Let him see death coming.

He drops the pick, falls to his knees, chittering what might be prayers or pleas. Doesn't matter. My boot crushes his windpipe.

The room goes quiet except for the hamstrung goblin's whimpering. I scan the spaceâ€”mining charts, duty rosters, payroll ledgers. And there, nailed to the wall with a pick through the center: the accident report log. The page is turned to last sennight. "Breakthrough into older workings. Three injuries. Unstable ground."

Below it, written in what looks like blood: "OURS NOW."

I finish the hamstrung goblin. The silence feels heavy, wrong. Through the window overlooking the main shaft, I see torchlight moving far below. Lots of torches. They're massing at the bottom, near the new breakthrough.[[Image: Seepwater pools in natural karst pockets; violet cave-caps fatten on bat guano and iron drip.
The goblins know these tunnels nowâ€”every twist, every dead end.

They're not running scared. They're leading me somewhere.

The passage opens into a natural cavern, ceiling lost in darkness. Water drips steady, has for centuries, forming pools that swallow my torchlight and give back only my face, distorted. The air tastes wrongâ€”thick, sporous, makes my throat itch.

White mushrooms carpet the far wall, each one the size of a dinner plate. Some pulse with internal light. The pools between me and them are still as glass, maybe ankle deep, maybe bottomless.

I see them nowâ€”five goblins crouched on the far side where the floor rises again. They're not attacking. They're waiting. One grins, showing filed teeth.

I step toward the water.

The instant my boot touches the pool's edge, the mushrooms explode.

Spores fill the airâ€”a white cloud that burns my eyes, my lungs. I stagger back, coughing. Through tears, I see the goblins moving, spreading out to flank. They knew exactly where I'd step, exactly when the spores would burst.

"Ventusfury!"

Wind tears through the cavern, but carefulâ€”too strong and I'll spread the spores everywhere. Just enough to create a clear channel of air. I pull my shirt over my mouth, breathe shallow.

They're coming through the water now, picks raised. The leader's halfway across when I spot itâ€”a miner's lamp still burning beneath the surface, its light wavering through two inches of crystal-clear water. A warning. Or bait.

He's been hiding underwater, breathing through a reed. His pick swings for my knee. I pivot, bring Whisperwind down in a silver arc. The blade cleaves through his skull, splits him to the teeth. Gore splashes into the pool, turning the water pink.

Two more rush from the left. My boots slip on the slick stoneâ€”exactly what they planned. I go down on one knee, Whisperwind coming up in a desperate parry. Their picks spark against the blade. One overextendsâ€”I grab his ankle, yank him into the water. He goes under thrashing.

Back on my feet. The remaining goblins circle, careful now. They've seen what Whisperwind can do. One feints left. I don't take the bait. Another throws a handful of mushroom pasteâ€”it splashes across my chest, burns through my shirt like acid.

Pain sharpens everything.

"Ignisurge!"

Fire blooms in my palm. Not at themâ€”at the water. Steam explodes upward, boiling the goblin I pulled under. His screams bubble up through the water. The steam also clears the spores, gives me room to breathe.

The last three charge together.

Whisperwind moves in the Ninth Formâ€”the Reaping Wind. The blade becomes a silver blur, impossible to track. I take the first goblin's arm at the elbow. The second loses his headâ€”it rolls into the pool with a splash. The third tries to run.

I let Whisperwind fly.

The blade spins through the air, guided by wind and will. It takes him between the shoulders, punches through his chest. He falls face-first into the shallow water, green blood spreading like oil.

I retrieve my sword, scan the cavern. No more movement. But on the far wall, carved in the stone beneath the mushroom grove: arrows pointing down, and below them, that same phrase in blood: "OURS NOW."

The passage continues, sloping sharper. I can hear drums nowâ€”deep, rhythmic. They know I'm coming.]Ventusfury.

I reverse the wind. The burning oil I'd pushed away now surges forward, riding my ice like a flaming wave. It washes up their legs, soaking into their rags.

Ignisurge.

One spark at chest height.

They ignite like torches. Screaming, thrashing, trying to beat out flames that won't die. The doorway clears as they stumble backward into their friends. Fire spreads through the clusterâ€”goblins are greasy creatures, they burn well.

I keep my ice shield raised, wind pushing smoke away from me. The screaming stops after four heartbeats. The crackling continues longer.

When it's done, I step through charred meat and melted fat. The smell would make a lesser man vomit. I've smelled worse.

The corridor opens into the main shaftâ€”a circular pit with wooden platforms spiraling down. More goblins below, their drums suddenly silent. They've heard their brothers die.

Fear makes them stupid.]Glacieshold.

Ice drops like a guillotine blade behind the jammed goblins, sealing them into the doorway. They're pressed between their dead brothers and my frozen wall.

Ignisurge.

I draw two fingers across the air. The heat-lance burns tiny holes through the ice at eye level. The beams punch throughâ€”one goblin loses an eye, another his throat. They can't even fall, packed too tight.

Ventusfury.

Wind presses against the ice wall. It groans, cracks, surges forward. The goblins compress. Bones snap like kindling. The ice shatters sideways in bloody chunks, taking most of them with it.

One survivor crawls from the wreckage, dragging himself by his fingernails. I step on his spine. Crunch.

The corridor opens into the main shaftâ€”a circular pit with wooden platforms spiraling down. More goblins below, watching me emerge from their dead brothers' tomb.

They've gone quiet. Smart ones are already backing toward the lower levels.]My boot scrapes the floor, deliberate. The oil-carrier flinches, jar sloshing. Perfect.

"Drop it," I tell him.

He doesn't. His grip tightens. Behind him, two others raise their bladesâ€”trying to find courage in fellowship. Adorable.

I kick the floor. My steel boot strikes sparks. One spark is all I need.

Ignisurge.

A line of fire races across the stone toward themâ€”controlled, precise, beautiful. The oil-carrier panics, tries to throw the jar. Too late. I'm already moving, two long strides and a leap off the tunnel wall. My armored knee catches the jar, driving it up under his chin.

The jar shatters. Oil sprays.

Mid-air, I twist, both hands spreading wide. Fire erupts from my palmsâ€”down and out, away from the beams, turning the oil mist into a rolling wave of flame that washes over the clustered goblins at knee height.

They scream. They burn. They fall.

I land in a crouch among the dying. One still moves, crawling. A quick burst of flame to his back ends it. Another tries to runâ€”fire licks his ankles, dropping him.

The tunnel behind me is clear. The tunnel ahead echoes with drums. They know I'm coming.

Good.]The oil-carrier clutches his jar like salvation. I'll make it his funeral pyre.

Ignisurge.

First fireballâ€”chest-high, quick as a curse. It hammers the lead goblin's shield, heat exploding along the stone wall. The shield drops, smoking. The goblin drops, screaming.

Without moving my feet, I scoop my left hand low. A second fireball rolls across the floor like a burning wheel, exploding at their shins. Two goblins dance backward, leather wrappings on fire.

The oil-carrier raises his jar, either to throw or drinkâ€”doesn't matter.

Third fireball. Overhand, like skipping a stone. It cracks the jar at the neck. Oil fountains forward, away from the ceiling beams, directly into my next gesture.

Ignisurge.

Fire streams from my palm, igniting the oil spray. The flame blooms outward in a tight cone, washing over the remaining goblins without touching timber. Controlled devastation. Surgical hellfire.

They're all screaming now. Some dropping, some running. One charges through the flame, blade raised, flesh already peeling. My plated fist meets his jaw. The blade clatters away as he falls.

I step through them while they burn. Each footfall deliberate, unhurried. A goblin on his knees tries to grab my leg. I press my palm to his headâ€”a brief touch of fire. He falls silent.

The last two back against the far wall, weapons forgotten. One pisses himself. The other whimpers something about 'Storak.'

I raise my hand. They run.

I snap my fingers three times. Each snap births a small flame that flies to the tunnel lanterns, lighting them in sequence. The space blooms orange and shadow. Any goblin watching from deeper in sees my silhouette framed in fire, stepping over their burning dead.[Choice: Continue to the main shaft.

passages.name: 01 shaft
passages.label: Shaft
passages.text:
The main shaft opens before me like a throat.

The hoist mechanism dominates the spaceâ€”massive wooden wheels and hemp ropes thick as my arm. The cage hangs halfway down, swaying slightly. Below it, lit by goblin torches, I see what the miners found.

They broke through into something ancient. The stone down there is differentâ€”black, polished, carved with symbols that squirm when you stare too long. K'tarran. Has to be.

A dozen goblins cluster around the breakthrough. One wears a headdress of human teeth and finger bonesâ€”their shaman. He's drumming on a shield, the rhythm matching something deeper, older. The stones themselves seem to pulse with it.

Between them and me: forty feet of vertical shaft and a half-lowered cage.

Time to remind them why humans conquered this world.

I grab the hoist rope, wrap it around my waist. Then I cut the brake.

The cage plummets. I plummet with it, controlling my descent just enough not to die. The goblins shriek, scatter. Twenty feet. Ten feet. Fiveâ€”

I let go.

Landing hard, I roll forward, come up with Whisperwind already moving. The blade takes the closest goblin across the belly. His guts spill onto stone older than kingdoms.

[Image: Another debt paid in the dark.

"Ventusfury!"

Wind explodes outward, sending three goblins tumbling. One goes over the edge into the shaftâ€”his scream echoes all the way down.

The shaman keeps drumming, faster now. The carved stones glow brighter.

Two goblins with shields block my path. They move together, trained. I feint left, they track. I go right, they're ready.

Fine.

[Battle]

passages.name: 01 combat minigame
passages.label: Combat Minigame
passages.text:
"Glacieshold!"

Ice spreads beneath their feet. They slip, shields dropping just an inch. Enough. Whisperwind threads the gap, opens the first one's throat. I shoulder-check the second, send him sliding across the ice into the wall. His skull cracks against stone.

The shaman's drumming reaches crescendo. The carved archway behind him starts to hum.

No more time for clean kills.

"Ignisurge!"

Fire erupts from both handsâ€”a roaring wave that washes over the remaining goblins. They scatter, burning, screaming. The shaman tries to maintain his rhythm but his headdress catches fire. He drops the drum, rolling on the ground.

I walk through the flames.

Too fast.

The ice I laidâ€”my own iceâ€”has melted in rivulets where the fire washed across it. The stone beneath shines wet, black, treacherous. My boot finds the slick and for one terrible instant I am not Aldric the Great, hero of Eboncrest, slayer of wyverns and trolls. I am simply a body obeying gravity.

My ankle rolls. Not badlyâ€”I've fought through worseâ€”but it costs me half a heartbeat. My weight shifts wrong. Whisperwind's arc falters mid-swing, her tip catching stone instead of goblin flesh, and the impact judders up through my wrist.

The goblin I meant to kill does not die.

He is small. Barely three feet, green as pond-scum, eyes like diseased egg-yolks. His pick is rusted iron that wouldn't cut cheese. He smells of piss and rotting meat and that sweet-sick musk that makes my stomach clench.

He does not swing at my chest or throat. A warrior would. A soldier would.

He swings at my knee.

The pick-point punches through the gap in my greave where the joint flexes. Not deepâ€”barely an inch of corroded metal in the meat behind my kneecapâ€”but the leg buckles. I go down on that knee, Whisperwind scraping sparks from stone, and the world narrows to a single point of white-hot wrongness where my body has been breached.

"GRASHK!" The goblin screams it like triumph. "GRASHK-THRACK! DOWN! DOWN!"

I bring Whisperwind around. The blade should take his head. Would have taken his head, if not for the second goblinâ€”the one I thought I'd killed against the wall, skull cracked, doneâ€”who has crawled through his own blood to wrap both arms around my sword-wrist.

His grip is nothing. Weak as a child's. I could shake him off in an instant.

But an instant is what I do not have.

The pick comes down again. Same knee. Deeper. I hear the crunch of metal on bone, feel it as a sound more than a sensation, and then I am falling sideways because that leg no longer answers to my will.

"Ventusâ€”"

A rock catches me across the templeâ€”dropped by the burned goblin who has stopped rolling and started killing. The word dies in my throat. Wind magic requires breath and focus; I have neither. Stars burst behind my eyes, hot and white, and through them I see shapes converging.

Three. Noâ€”four. The ones I burned are dead, truly dead, but I miscounted in my hubris. There were more in the shadows.

"Humie bleeds," one rasps.

They do not rush. They have learned, these goblins. Learned from watching their kind die, learned from the stories whispered around their dung-fires, learned that even a wounded hero can take lives if you give him room to swing.

They circle.

I try to rise. My ruined knee screams and folds. I catch myself on one hand, Whisperwind still clutched in the other, and for a moment I am simply a man on all fours in a hole in the earth, bleeding onto stone that doesn't care.

"Fire-man," the shaman wheezes. He has crawled back from the archway, hand crushed, headdress gone, patches of his scalp showing pink and weeping where his hair burned away. But he is smiling. "Fire-man got no fire now."

He's right.

The flame-casting drained me. The ice before it drained me further. I have enough left for one spell, maybe two, but not enough to clear the room. Not enough to kill four goblins and a shaman and make it back up that shaft and ride home to Elara.

Elara.

The thought of her face breaks something loose in my chest. I roarâ€”formless, animalâ€”and lunge at the nearest goblin. Whisperwind takes his arm off at the elbow. But my lunge becomes a fall, because you cannot lunge on a knee that is more hole than joint, and I go down hard on my shoulder and the impact tears Whisperwind from my grip.

She spins away across the wet stone. The skyforged blade that has drunk the blood of a hundred monsters comes to rest against the shaman's ruined hand.

He picks her up.

"Booyagh," he breathes, and his eyes go wide at the hum of wind-runes against his palm. "Booyagh-sparkly."[Choice: They take their time...]"Glacieshold!"

Ice spreads beneath their feet. They slip, shields dropping just an inch. That's all I need. Whisperwind threads the gap, opens the first one's throat. I shoulder-check the second, send him sliding across the ice into the wall. His skull cracks against stone.

The shaman's drumming reaches crescendo. The carved archway behind him starts to hum.

No more time for clean kills.

"Ignisurge!"

Fire erupts from both handsâ€”a roaring wave that washes over the remaining goblins. They scatter, burning, screaming. The shaman tries to maintain his rhythm but his headdress catches fire. He drops the drum, rolling on the ground.

I stride through the dying heat. Whisperwind finds each burning goblin, ends their agony quick.

The shaman crawls toward the archway, reaching for somethingâ€”a horn made from human bone.

My boot comes down on his hand. Bones crack like twigs.

He looks up at me, eyes wild with pain and a terror that has nothing to do with me.

"Too late," he gasps in broken common tongue. "Already... waking..."

Whisperwind through his eye ends his riddles.

The silence after slaughter always feels wrong. Blood steams on cold stone. The shaman's drum rolls to a stop against my boot.

I kick it aside and study the breach.

The miners' picks punched through limestone into something else entirely. The hole is ragged on this side, but beyond itâ€”the stone is smooth as a drowned man's eye, black as the space between stars.

[Choice: Step through the breach.]

passages.name: 01 die
passages.label: Die
passages.text:
They take their time.

This is what I learn in the space between living and dying: goblins are patient when the outcome is assured. They are not berserkers drunk on violence. They are scavengers, carrion-feeders, and they have learned across a thousand generations that thrashing prey injures scavengers. So they wait and let me bleed.

The shaman crouches just out of reach, Whisperwind laid across his knees like a trophy. He strokes her blade with his good hand, leaving smears of green-black blood on skyforged steel. "Pretty," he murmurs. "Pretty-sharp. Cut-cut-cut all the Grikzit boys."

"Grikzit," I repeat. The word comes out wrong, bubbled through something wet in my throat. "That's your tribe."

"Grikzit strongest." He shows his teeth. They are filed to points, stained yellow-brown, and several are missing.

I try to wipe it away. My arms don't want to cooperate. One of the goblinsâ€”I've stopped tracking which is whichâ€”has tied my wrists behind my back with a leather cord that might be human skin. The binding isn't tight. It doesn't need to be. I cannot rise.

"Twelve Grikzit this morning," the shaman continues. "Twelve. Now four. Four and Grubnoz." He taps his chest. "Grubnoz. Remember name, fire-man. Grubnoz the one who kills Aldric the Great."

"Grubnoz," I manage. "Let's... negotiate."

The goblins cackle, high-pitched and wet, slapping their thighs with hands still crusted in their brothers' blood. One of them laughs so hard he falls over.

"Negotiate," Grubnoz repeats, savoring the word. "Fire-man wants to negotiate. What fire-man got to trade? Shinies?" He reaches down, fumbles at my belt, finds my purse. Empties it. The coins scatter across black stone, winking in the torchlight. "Got these already."

"More," I say. "My house. Eboncrest. I'm rich."

"Rich." Grubnoz tilts his head, considering. "Rich in humie-town. Town with walls. Town with guards." He shakes his head sadly. "Grubnoz not go to humie-town. Grubnoz stay here. Stay in dark. Safe in dark."

"Then what do you want?"

Grubnoz smiles. The expression transforms his face into something worse than hatefulâ€”something genuinely pleased.

"What Grubnoz want?" He gestures at the carved archway behind him, the black stone that hums with frequencies that nest behind my eyes like wasps. "Grubnoz want what sleeping here. Old god. Old power. Grikzit find it, dig it up, wake it up."

He stops. Looks down at me.

"Fire-man dying. Fire-man want to knowâ€”" He leans close, close enough that I can smell the rot-sweet of his breath, see the mucus glistening in his nostrils. "â€”what happen to fire-man before fire-man dies?"

The cold is spreading up from my knee, and I realize distantly that the pick must have severed something important, some vessel that's emptying me onto the ancient stone one pulse at a time.

"Grubnoz tell you." He settles back on his haunches, begins counting on his fingers. "First, Grikzit boys take fire-man's armor. Good armor. Booyagh-metal. Sell to other tribes, get many-many for it."

One of the goblins is already working at my pauldron, his claws scratching against the steel.

"Then, Grikzit boys take fire-man's fingers." Grubnoz waggles his own. "Fire-man make magic with fingers, yes? Make theâ€”" He mimes my hand-gestures, the Telenil forms I use for battle-casting. "â€”the sparkly-shapes. No fingers, no shapes. No shapes, no magic."

The cold reaches my hip. I try to move my toes and feel nothing.

"Then eyes. Then tongue. Thenâ€”" He shrugs. "Then whatever Grikzit boys want. They angry, fire-man. You burn their brothers. They want to burn you back, butâ€”" Another shrug. "â€”Grubnoz say no fire. Fire-man dies slow."

The goblin at my shoulder finally tears the pauldron free. Cold air touches the sweat-soaked linen beneath. Another goblin starts on my greavesâ€”the one that isn't destroyed, the one still protecting a leg that can feel.

"You talk too much," I tell Grubnoz. "You should have killed me while I was down."

Grubnoz laughs. "Fire-man still think he wins? Fire-man can't move legs. Can't move arms. Can'tâ€”"

"Ignisurge."

The word comes out as a whisper. A breath shaped around desperate intention, and my hands aren't even in position because my hands are tied behind my back.

But Gannis taught me that magic isn't about the hands. Not really. The hands focus. The breath carries. The *will* ignites.

Fire blooms between my shoulder blades.

The leather bindings crisp and part. The goblin behind me screams as his arms catchâ€”he was too close, greedy fingers working at my backplate, and now those fingers are burning. I roll, agony spiking through my ruined knee, and my freed hands come up with flames still licking between them.

Grubnoz scrambles backward. "KILL! KILL HIM NOW!"

But I'm not aiming for Grubnoz.

I'm aiming for the ceiling.

The mine supports. The ancient timber that holds up a thousand tons of rock and earth. The wood that has been soaking in groundwater for decades, rotting slowly, waiting for something to push it past the point of endurance.

"IGNISURGE!"

This one comes out right. All my training, all my rage, all the love I have for a woman with autumn hair and steady handsâ€”I pour it into the word and the word becomes fire and the fire becomes a lance of pure destruction that punches through the nearest support beam and into the stone beyond.

For a moment, nothing happens.

Then the ceiling groans.

Grubnoz's eyes go wide. He scrambles for the breach in the wall, the passage into the K'tarran ruins where something old and terrible sleeps. The other goblins scatter, shrieking, some toward the main shaft and some deeper into the tunnels and some simply running in circles because fear has eaten their minds.

I can't run. Can't even crawl. The magic took everything I had left, and now I am simply meat on stone, watching the cracks spread across the ceiling like dark lightning.

"Elara," I say.

A chunk of limestone the size of a cart crashes down three feet from my head. Dust fills the air, thick and choking. Through it, I see Grubnoz's shape disappearing through the breach, Whisperwind still clutched in his hand.

He's taking my sword into that darkness. Into whatever sleeps beneath these ruins.

Another impact. Closer. The ground shakes, and somewhere in the chaos I hear the main shaft collapsing, the wooden platforms splintering, the escape route I'll never use folding in on itself.

"Elara."

I close my eyes.

passages.name: 01 ruins
passages.label: Ruins
passages.text:
[Image: Pillars thick as ancient oaks march in rows, disappearing into darkness my torch can't pierce.

The temperature drops twenty degrees the moment I cross through.

My breath mists. Carved blocks of stone, each one larger than a house, fitted so tight a razor couldn't find the seam. No mortar. No need.

The floor slopes down into a vast chamber. The stone is the same black material, but here it's carved with shapesâ€”suggestions of things that shouldn't existâ€”too many eyes, angles that fold back on themselves, mouths where mouths shouldn't be.

The air tastes of copper and old death. Older than rot. The exhalation of tombs sealed before men scratched their first words in clay.

Movement in the shadows. Three goblins crouch near a collapsed section of wall, pawing through rubble. They haven't seen me yet. One's massiveâ€”squat, all muscle and gut, cock swinging free and slapping his thigh with each step. The thing's as long as my forearm and leaking. Goblins.

The big one finds somethingâ€”a tarnished amulet. He bites it, testing for gold.

[Choice: Attack them.

passages.name: 01 pursue
passages.label: Pursue
passages.text:
I drop from the elevated entrance, fifteen feet straight down.

The first goblin looks up just as my boots crush his ribcage. Bones snap like dry branches. His eyes bulge, blood frothing from his mouth. I roll forward off his corpse, Whisperwind already singing.

The second goblin fumbles for a rusty blade.

"Ignisurge!"

Fire erupts point-blank into his face. His skull goes up like a pitch-soaked rag. He runs three steps, four, then collapses. The smell of burning meat and hair fills the chamber.

The big oneâ€”he's already moving. Not toward me, but away, surprisingly fast for something carrying that much meat between its legs. He vaults over a low wall, that obscene appendage flopping wildly.

I pursue.

The chamber opens into what must have been a plaza. A dry fountain dominates the center, its basin filled with bones so old they've gone to powder. Stone benches ring the space. Buildingsâ€”or what's left of themâ€”rise on all sides, their doorways gaping like mouths.

The goblin scrambles up a wide staircase carved into the chamber wall. I follow, taking the steps three at a time.

"Ventusfury!"

Wind howls up the stairwell, meant to knock him down. He ducks into an alcove at the last second. My wind tears past, accomplishing nothing but stirring tomb-dust.

"Clever little shit," I mutter.

He's running again, that massive cock bouncing off his thighs with each step. How does he even move that fast? The stairs spiral up along the chamber wall. Fifty feet. Seventy. A hundred. My legs burn but I keep climbing.

The stairs end at a bridgeâ€”narrow, no rails, spanning a chasm I can't see the bottom of. The goblin's halfway across, arms out for balance.

"Glacieshold!"

Ice races across the bridge. The goblin sees it coming, leaps for the far side. His fingers catch the edge. That ridiculous member swings like a pendulum as he dangles.

I charge across the ice-slicked bridge. He's pulling himself up. My sword comes downâ€”

He lets go.

The bastard lets go, dropping onto a hidden ledge ten feet below. I nearly go over the edge trying to stop.

"STAND AND DIE!" I roar.

His only response is that chittering laugh as he disappears into another passage.

[Choice: Follow him deeper.

passages.name: 01 collar
passages.label: Collar
passages.text:
The passage opens into what can only be a temple.

The ceiling vanishes into darkness. Carved figures cover every surfaceâ€”things that demanded worship. Many-eyed things. Things with too many mouths. The same nightmare geometry from the pillars, but more deliberate here. More focused.

An altar dominates the far end, black stone stained darker with old blood. The goblin scrambles over it, knocking aside pottery shards and rusted implements.

Behind the altar, partially buried in rubble: a metal chest. The lock's already broken, lid hanging open.

"Ignisurge!"

My fireball explodes against the altar. Stone chips fly. The goblin yelps, dives behind the chest.

I advance, Whisperwind ready. He's trapped now. Nowhere left to run.

That's when I see what he's holding.

It's a collarâ€”iron, but wrong somehow. The metal seems to drink light rather than reflect it. Symbols writhe across its surface, similar to the wall carvings but smaller, more concentrated. Just looking at it makes my teeth ache.

The goblin holds it like a shield, eyes wide with terror. His cock has finally shrunk back, fear overwhelming even goblin biology.

"Drop it," I command.

He throws it at me.

Clumsy with terror. Awkward and wild. I sidestep easily, butâ€”

The collar hits Whisperwind.

The sword screamsâ€”a sound no steel should make, a shriek from somewhere deeper than metal. The blade jerks in my hand like a living thing trying to flee.

The collar bounces off, lands on the stone between us. We both stare at it.

The goblin moves first, scrambling to grab it again. I lunge forward, boot coming down where his hand would be. He jerks back. I swing Whisperwind in a killing arcâ€”

The collar springs open.

No one touched it. It just... opens. A mouth made of hunger.

Dark energy bleeds from itâ€”visible, black, alive. It ignores the goblin entirely and lunges for me.

Whisperwind comes up. The darkness splits around the blade and reforms behind it, tightening like a noose.

The collar hits my palm an inch from my throat. The metal burns so cold my fingers die instantlyâ€”just gone, wooden stumps wrapped around iron that writhes with symbols crawling like fat black beetles across its surface.

The goblin's backing away, terrified.

The collar pulls harder. My arm shakes with the effort of holding it back. Whisperwind falls from my other handâ€”I need both hands now, fighting this thing that wants my throat.

"Ignisurge!"

Fire washes over the collar. It doesn't even warm.

"Glacieshold!"

Ice encases it. The collar shatters the ice from within.

My knees buckle. The collar's winning. Inch by inch, it moves toward my throat. The symbols glow now, purple-black like bruises, like the space between stars.

The goblin's almost at the door. He looks back once, sees me losing, and does something unexpected.

He laughs.

A sound like cracked potteryâ€”all nerves, no triumph. Like he can't believe what's happening either.

Ice races through my veins. Older than Glacieshold. Meaner. My vision fractures. I see the temple as it wasâ€”filled with worshippers in black robes, the altar wet with sacrifice, something vast and terrible accepting their offerings.

Then darkness. Complete and total.

The last thing I hear is the goblin's feet slapping on stone as he runs.

The last thing I think is: Elara, I'm sorry.

[Choice: Everything goes black...

passages.name: 02 Wake up
passages.label: Wake Up
passages.text:
--- Chapter 2: The Collar ---
The dream tears at me like wolves.

Elara's in our bed, but something's wrongâ€”her belly swells with child, but when she turns to me, her eyes are yellow. Goblin yellow. She opens her mouth to speak and that chittering language spills out, wet and wrong. I try to scream but my voice comes out in the same foul tongueâ€”

[Video]

Cold stone slaps me awake.

My skull throbs. Each heartbeat hammers against bone like a smith working iron. The taste of copper coats my throat. Where... the mine. The ruins. That green bastard with the collarâ€”

I try to sit up.

Weight drags at my ribs. Two masses of flesh, heavy as saddlebags, pulling me forward before I've finished moving. They swing when I stopâ€”a sickening delay, like carrying something alive that doesn't know I've changed direction.

My hand goes to check for wounds and sinks knuckle-deep into warm, yielding meat that overflows my grip.

Growing from my chest. Part of me.

Each gasp lifts them against my fingers and drops them againâ€”warm dough that won't stop moving. Metal scales bite crescents into skin so tender my jaw locks. Cold air finds my stomach, my ribs, acres of bare skin where mail and leather should be.

I force myself upright. The titsâ€”call them what they areâ€”lurch forward with my momentum, then rebound against my ribs hard enough to make me gag. I pitch forward like a ship taking on water. My hands shoot out and I see them in the cave-moss glow.

Hands like a noblewoman'sâ€”tapered fingers without a single callus, smooth as if they'd never gripped anything heavier than embroidery silk.

[Image: No. No no no.

Hair falls across my visionâ€”a black curtain that wasn't there this morning. I shake my head and feel the weight of it sweep past my shoulder blades, clinging to sweat-damp skin all the way to my waist.

I look down.

Two obscene mounds strain against metal triangles that wouldn't cover a man's palm. These hands are smaller. Everything is smaller except what hangs from my chest. The plates are connected by thin chains that dig into the soft meat, leaving red marks. Below them, my stomach is bare, pale, soft. No scars. No muscle. Just smooth skin leading down to where a metal strap barely wider than my thumb crosses my hips, diving betweenâ€”

The space between my thighs is smooth. Sealed shut. Where my cock should be there's just a cleft of yielding flesh that the air touches like a wound.

My hands fly to my throat. Cold iron. A collar that grinds against my windpipe when I swallow. Something hums inside itâ€”a vibration like pressing your ear to a wasp nest, patient and full of purpose.

This isn't my body. Every nerve ending disagrees. Gooseflesh on acres of bare skin. Metal biting into places I never had. The drag of tits I can't put down, and between my legs, an emptiness that aches like a missing tooth the size of my fist.

My voice catches in my throat. When I swallow, the collar constricts.

[Choice: Try to stand up.

passages.name: 02 finding out
passages.label: Finding Out
passages.text:
I plant my palms on cold stone and push.

My legs straighten and the boots pitch me onto metal spikes where heels should be. My calves seize instantlyâ€”tendons stretched to snapping, ankles wobbling on points no wider than arrow-tips. The tits launch forward before I've finished standing, dragging my whole center of gravity with them. I windmill backward but the boots won't let me plant my feet flat. They force everything into a curve: chest forward, spine arched, ass thrust back, the whole body arranged around a pair of metal stakes and the desperate wish not to fall.

My thighs press togetherâ€”soft as bread dough, sliding against each other with a friction that shouldn't exist. Fat thighs. Woman's thighs that kiss when I walk. The metal strap between my legs rides up, cutting into places thatâ€”

*Crack.*

My ass hits stone hard enough to rattle my teethâ€”and keeps hitting, the impact rippling through flesh that won't stop moving. My tits fly up and slam back down, my ass spreads beneath me like warm clay, and when my hands shoot back to catch myself they sink wrist-deep into asscheek. I'm sitting on my own body fat and it's still jiggling three seconds after I've stopped.

"Flux's balls!"

The voice that comes out is a soprano bell. Clear, musical, the kind of voice bards write about. From MY throat.

The ancient city. I'm still in the ruins. That goblinâ€”where is he? My hand goes to my sword but finds only bare hip, soft and yielding. No weapon belt. No weapon. Just smooth skin and that metal strap that digs in when I twist.

I look down at my legs properly for the first time. Black metal encases them from mid-thigh down, articulated plates that should be armor but aren't. The plates stop at the ankle, then the metal continues but wrongâ€”the foot is arched severely, forcing me onto a narrow point no wider than a spear butt. A spike of metal extends down from the heel. No wonder I can't fucking walk.

[Image: These aren't soldier's boots. They're... something else.

No soldier ever wore these. The arch forces my weight forward, the spike forces my ass back, and the wobble forces my hips to sway with every step. Armor for a body meant to be watched, not to fight.

The collar pulses at my throat. Patient. Promising.

I need to see. Need to understand what's been done to me. The bioluminescent moss casts everything in pale green shadow, but thereâ€”a puddle of water, still and dark as a scrying mirror.

passages.name: 02 reflection
passages.label: Reflection
passages.text:
[[Image: These massive, hanging things are part of my body.
My hands move to the weights hanging from my chest.

Sweet merciful Eon, they're attached to me.

The flesh gives under my fingers like dough left to rise too longâ€”warm, yielding. And I can feel my own touch THROUGH it. When I press, the meat compresses and bulges sideways between my fingers, more than two hands can hold. Pressure from inside AND outside simultaneouslyâ€”I'm groping myself and being groped at the same time, and my brain can't reconcile the two.

I try to lift one. The weight shocks meâ€”heavy as a full waterskin but shapeless, filling my grip and oozing between my fingers like something alive. The metal triangle covers maybe a third of it. The rest spills around the edges, angry red crescents bitten into pale skin. When I let go, it drops and SLAPS my ribs hard enough to sting.

[Image: The metal triangles barely cover anything. My fingers find soft flesh spilling out around the edges, warm and yielding like overripe fruit in summer heat.

My strength is gone. These arms that once hefted a zweihander now struggle with the weight of... of these things. I try to flex, to summon the power that should be there, but the muscle is buried under softness. My arms are slender, weak, made for needlework not swordwork.

When I lean forward to stand, they swing. The momentum nearly topples me againâ€”first the fall forward, then the flesh following a heartbeat later, then the backward pull as they settle. My hands fly up instinctively to stop their movement and I feel them overflow my palms, soft and warm and wrong. The metal triangles dig deeper with each bounce, leaving marks I can feel burning into the tender skin.

Where my chest should be hard with muscle, carved from years of swordwork, there's just... yielding softness. I press where my pectorals should be and find only these mounds that compress and spring back with a elasticity that makes my stomach lurch. They're sensitive tooâ€”when the cold metal shifts, I feel it like needles. When air moves across the exposed flesh, goosebumps rise.

The puddle. I crawl toward it on hands and knees because standing in these metal torture-boots is impossible. "IGNISURGE!"

The word tears from my throat with the force of seventeen years' practice. I feel it buildingâ€”that sweet familiar rush, like molten gold flooding my veins. passages.name: 04 hut
